hanzi-su-wiki:
徳

Значения

Добродетель, нравственность

Мнемоника

Упрощено. Справа — прямизна 直 сердца 心 добродетель. Действуй 彳 и твори добро. Германия — добродетельная страна, образец для подражания.

Варианты

德, 悳

德德RS
徳徳		virtue, ethics
  • RS. walk 彳 a straight 𢛳 road

  • walk 彳 with an honest heart 𢛳
heisig_constituent: benevolence, Nelson, column, going, line, stethoscope, camel, ten, needle, eye, cross-eyed, net, heart
heisig_story: Going . . . needle . . . eye . . . heart. Refer back now to the note in frame 890.
koohiiStory1: Hearkening back to the kanji for LISTEN... Benevolence is a good listener who is willing to go the distance to help.
koohiiStory2: In a rare act of benevolence, the Sparten column removes the needle from the cyclops´s eye, and he repays them by eating their hearts.
WaniKani_Radicals: 彳, 十, 罒, 心
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: You're loitering, staring down at the cross that got caught in the net of your heart, because it's trying to teach you to act with virtue.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: People who keep the cross in their hearts are supposed to be full of virtue, always doing the right thing, always helping others. But you aren't sure if you want to be virtuous, it's a lot of responsibility. So you look down at this symbolic cross and loiter instead of making a decision.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: As you try to decide if you want to live a life of virtue the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you. He points to your heart and the cross, then points to his own and you see a glowing cross in his own.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: I don't know about you, but I'm pretty sure Tokugawa Ieyasu is telling you to choose a life of virtue.
Ru_Radicals: 十 (десять), 彳 (шаг), 心 (сердце), 買 (покупать)
Kanshudo_mnemonic: the ten (十) nets (罒) of your heart (心) take a step (彳) towards benevolence

徳字的汉语字典释义

[①]［déㄉ］
同“德1”。
《宋元以来俗字谱》：“德”，《列女传》、《金瓶梅》等作“徳”。按，亦为日本用简体字。

Same as "De 1".
"Song and Yuan Dynasties": "De", "De" in "Biography of Women", "Jin Ping Mei" and so on. Press, it is also a simplified Chinese character used in Japan.

Name meaning
Germany.
dé
яп. вм. 德
Radicals: 彳, 十, 罒, 心  (loiter, cross, net, heart)
Meaning Mnemonic
You're loitering, staring down at the cross that got caught in the net of your heart, because it's trying to teach you to act with virtue.
People who keep the cross in their hearts are supposed to be full of virtue, always doing the right thing, always helping others. But you aren't sure if you want to be virtuous, it's a lot of responsibility. So you look down at this symbolic cross and loiter instead of making a decision.
Reading Mnemonic
As you try to decide if you want to live a life of virtue the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you. He points to your heart and the cross, then points to his own and you see a glowing cross in his own.
I don't know about you, but I'm pretty sure Tokugawa Ieyasu is telling you to choose a life of virtue.
